articles.headline: Citing Climate Change, Obama Rejects Construction of Keystone XL Oil Pipeline
articles.snippet: The president’s decision was a major victory for environmentalists and a bitter loss for the oil industry.
articles.abstract: The president’s decision was a major victory for environmentalists and a bitter loss for the oil industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced on Friday that he had rejected the request from a Canadian company to build the Keystone XL oil pipeline, ending a seven-year review that had become a symbol of the debate over his climate policies.

articles.headline: A Hedge Fund Sales Pitch Casts a Spell on Public Pensions
articles.snippet: Despite hedge funds’ high fees and underwhelming performance this year, most public pension funds have not followed Calpers in its move away from them.
articles.abstract: Despite hedge funds’ high fees and underwhelming performance this year, most public pension funds have not followed Calpers in its move away from them.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been just over a year since the California Public Employees’ Retirement System said it would wind down its $4 billion portfolio of hedge fund holdings. High costs and complexity made the vehicles “no longer warranted,” Calpers said at the time.

articles.headline: Ben Carson Resists Challenges to the Life Story He Rode to Political Prominence
articles.snippet: Ben Carson acknowledged never having applied to West Point, despite assertions over the years that implied he had been accepted there.
articles.abstract: Ben Carson acknowledged never having applied to West Point, despite assertions over the years that implied he had been accepted there.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his rise to the top of the crowded field for the Republican presidential nomination, Ben Carson has endeared himself to conservatives with his inspirational tale of emerging from a single-parent home to become an internationally renowned pediatric neurosurgeon.

articles.headline: If Jobs Report Heralds a Solid Upturn, Democrats’ Fortunes May Also Rise
articles.snippet: A more tangible economic upswing could help Democrats keep the White House after the Obama administration’s long struggle with slow economic recovery.
articles.abstract: A more tangible economic upswing could help Democrats keep the White House after the Obama administration’s long struggle with slow economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Friday’s surprisingly robust jobs report cheered Democrats hoping to retain the White House and capture the Senate next year, but it heralded a new atmosphere of uncertainty by flashing a green light to the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, which could undermine economic growth.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Financial Advice for Women, From Women
articles.snippet: A spate of new robo-adviser financial sites aimed at women look to empower them to build net worth, rather than offer household budgeting advice.
articles.abstract: A spate of new robo-adviser financial sites aimed at women look to empower them to build net worth, rather than offer household budgeting advice.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been a long time since a talking teenage Barbie doll uttered the words, “Math class is tough!” That was 1992, and the uproar that ensued caused Mattel to banish the words from Barbie’s vocabulary.

articles.headline: Hundreds of Nude Photos Jolt Colorado School
articles.snippet: The authorities were debating whether to file child pornography charges, including felony charges, in the sexting case at Cañon City High School.
articles.abstract: The authorities were debating whether to file child pornography charges, including felony charges, in the sexting case at Cañon City High School.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAÑON CITY, Colo. — At least 100 students at a high school in Cañon City traded naked pictures of themselves, the authorities said Friday, part of a large sexting ring.
articles.byline: By Kassondra Cloos and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: Resisting Bomb Theory, Egypt Finds Itself Increasingly Alone
articles.snippet: As Britain, the United States and Russia take steps to protect their citizens, Egypt’s public statements recalled the 1999 crash of an EgyptAir flight near Nantucket.
articles.abstract: As Britain, the United States and Russia take steps to protect their citizens, Egypt’s public statements recalled the 1999 crash of an EgyptAir flight near Nantucket.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Six days after the crash of a Russian charter flight from the Egyptian resort area of Sharm el Sheikh, the government of Egypt is finding itself increasingly isolated in its resistance to the possibility that a terrorist’s bomb brought down the plane.

articles.headline: A Tough Year for Hedge Funds? Not That Real Estate Has Noticed
articles.snippet: Larry Robbins, head of Glenview Capital Management, is said to have bought a $37.9 million penthouse in Manhattan, a move that shows that despite a rough year, hedge fund managers aren’t hurting.
articles.abstract: Larry Robbins, head of Glenview Capital Management, is said to have bought a $37.9 million penthouse in Manhattan, a move that shows that despite a rough year, hedge fund managers aren’t hurting.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan penthouse on the Upper East Side with sweeping views of both the Hudson River and the East River was sold this summer for $37.9 million. The person behind the purchase was hidden behind a limited liability company with the cryptic name CRE Acquisition.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Gaps in Egyptian Airport Security Face Scrutiny After Crash
articles.snippet: Inconsistencies in airport security in Egypt are now under a spotlight as evidence from the crash of a Russian charter jet points to the possibility of a bombing.
articles.abstract: Inconsistencies in airport security in Egypt are now under a spotlight as evidence from the crash of a Russian charter jet points to the possibility of a bombing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The airport is surrounded by a wall topped with barbed wire. Armed sentries are stationed at its entrance, and passengers pass through two security screenings before reaching departure gates; before a recent flight, there were no fewer than eight uniformed guards standing around the checkpoint.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim, David D. Kirkpatrick and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: As U.S. Escalates Air War on ISIS, Allies Slip Away
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have shifted most of their aircraft away from Syria as they fight Houthi rebels in Yemen.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have shifted most of their aircraft away from Syria as they fight Houthi rebels in Yemen.
articles.lead_paragraph: AL UDEID AIR BASE, Qatar — As the United States prepares to intensify airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria, the Arab allies who with great fanfare sent warplanes on the initial missions there a year ago have largely vanished from the campaign.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: China’s Winemakers Seek Their Own Napa Valley
articles.snippet: Wines produced in a rocky, arid region on the edge of the Gobi Desert have won prestigious awards, and foreign investors have taken notice.
articles.abstract: Wines produced in a rocky, arid region on the edge of the Gobi Desert have won prestigious awards, and foreign investors have taken notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: YINCHUAN, China — On a fall evening in a fluorescent-lit classroom at Tsinghua University in Beijing, a dozen students listened intently. The speaker, Emma Gao, held a glass to the light and asked them to study the swirling liquid inside. Tsinghua is known as the “M.I.T. of China,” but this was no freshman seminar in fluid mechanics. It was a gathering of the student wine club.

articles.headline: Candidates Stick to Script, if Not the Truth, in the 2016 Race
articles.snippet: Deep disregard for the news media has allowed candidates to ridicule assertions from outlets they dislike as they play loose with the facts.
articles.abstract: Deep disregard for the news media has allowed candidates to ridicule assertions from outlets they dislike as they play loose with the facts.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I only tell true stories,” Carly Fiorina assured employees during one of her first speeches as the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard in 2000.

articles.headline: Web Poets’ Society: New Breed Succeeds in Taking Verse Viral
articles.snippet: Young, digitally astute poets with loyal online followings have catapulted onto the best-seller lists, where poetry books are scarce.
articles.abstract: Young, digitally astute poets with loyal online followings have catapulted onto the best-seller lists, where poetry books are scarce.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday night, Tyler Knott Gregson, a blond, tattooed poet from Montana, took the stage at a Manhattan bookstore and beamed at the crowd that had come to celebrate his new haiku collection.

articles.headline: Mississippi Flag, a Rebel Holdout, Is in a New Fight
articles.snippet: With the closing of the polls on Tuesday night, what could turn out to be the last battle over the Confederate battle flag in Mississippi has begun in earnest.
articles.abstract: With the closing of the polls on Tuesday night, what could turn out to be the last battle over the Confederate battle flag in Mississippi has begun in earnest.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Miss. — In single strokes after the massacre of nine black churchgoers in Charleston in June, Confederate battle flags were taken from statehouse grounds in South Carolina and Alabama, pulled from shelves at major retailers like Walmart and declared unwelcome, if to limited effect, at Nascar races.

articles.headline: Galvanized by VW Scandal, E.P.A. Expands On-Road Emissions Testing
articles.snippet: Regulators have begun testing all makes and models of diesel vehicles, at random and in real-world conditions, to try to increase the odds of catching automakers seeking to evade emissions standards.
articles.abstract: Regulators have begun testing all makes and models of diesel vehicles, at random and in real-world conditions, to try to increase the odds of catching automakers seeking to evade emissions standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Concerned that cheating on vehicle emissions could be prevalent across the automobile industry, regulators in the United States and Canada are significantly expanding their on-the-road emissions tests to cover all makes and models of diesel cars.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: G.O.P. Candidates, Lagging, Rely on New Hampshire to Get Close
articles.snippet: Jeb Bush, Chris Christie and John R. Kasich are trying to climb their way back in the presidential race by winning over voters with personal encounters in small towns, schools and senior centers.
articles.abstract: Jeb Bush, Chris Christie and John R. Kasich are trying to climb their way back in the presidential race by winning over voters with personal encounters in small towns, schools and senior centers.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — Jeb Bush rolled across this state last week in a bus, chomping on turkey jerky and ducking into diners, general stores and town halls to plead his case to voters.

articles.headline: Black Football Players Lend Heft to Protests at Missouri
articles.snippet: Dozens of players have joined demonstrations over the university’s handling of racial tensions on campus, vowing to skip team activities until the president resigns or is removed.
articles.abstract: Dozens of players have joined demonstrations over the university’s handling of racial tensions on campus, vowing to skip team activities until the president resigns or is removed.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Students at the University of Missouri have been demonstrating for weeks for the ouster of the university president, protesting the school’s handling of racial tensions. But their movement received a boost over the weekend when dozens of black football players issued a blunt ultimatum: Resign or they won’t play.
articles.byline: By Marc Tracy and Ashley Southall

articles.headline: A Texas Utility Offers a Nighttime Special: Free Electricity
articles.snippet: TXU Energy promotes a plan with free electricity overnight, in part a result of the ample wind power in Texas.
articles.abstract: TXU Energy promotes a plan with free electricity overnight, in part a result of the ample wind power in Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — In Texas, wind farms are generating so much energy that some utilities are giving power away.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Diane Cardwell

articles.headline: TED Prize Goes to Archaeologist Who Combats Looting With Satellite Technology
articles.snippet: An archaeologist’s quest to track illicit digs at ancient sites, part of a global effort to stop such activity, has received a $1 million TED prize.
articles.abstract: An archaeologist’s quest to track illicit digs at ancient sites, part of a global effort to stop such activity, has received a $1 million TED prize.
articles.lead_paragraph: Her laptop brims with satellite images pitted with thousands of black dots, evidence of excavations across Egypt where looters have tunneled in search of mummies, jewelry and other valuables prized by collectors, advertised in auction catalogs and trafficked on eBay, a criminal global black market estimated in the billions of dollars.
articles.byline: By Ralph Blumenthal and Tom Mashberg

articles.headline: Obama and Netanyahu: A Story of Slights and Crossed Signals
articles.snippet: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel arrives at the White House on Monday, he and President Obama have reasons to put the past behind them.
articles.abstract: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel arrives at the White House on Monday, he and President Obama have reasons to put the past behind them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, it was a day of celebration. He had just signed the most important domestic measure of his presidency, his health care program. So when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel arrived at the White House for a hastily arranged visit, it was likely not the main thing on his mind.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline: Peabody Energy Agrees to Greater Disclosures of Financial Risks
articles.snippet: The coal giant’s concessions came in response to a two-year investigation by the New York attorney general.
articles.abstract: The coal giant’s concessions came in response to a two-year investigation by the New York attorney general.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peabody Energy, the world’s biggest private sector coal company, has agreed to make more robust disclosures to its investors about the financial risks it faces from future government policies and regulations related to climate change and other environmental issues that could reduce demand for its product.

articles.headline: Bonus Pay on Wall Street Is Likely to Fall, a Report Says
articles.snippet: A report predicts that bonuses in the financial industry will fall 5 to 10 percent this year, drawing more young talent to a booming Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: A report predicts that bonuses in the financial industry will fall 5 to 10 percent this year, drawing more young talent to a booming Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as they emerge from the post-financial-crisis haze, bankers are seeing few signs that their institutions — and their bonuses — will stage a full recovery anytime soon.

articles.headline: In the Stream of Internet Radio, Music Stations Hold Their Own
articles.snippet: Successful stations are venturing into online streaming, but also playing to traditional strengths like thoughtfully curating playlists and championing new artists.
articles.abstract: Successful stations are venturing into online streaming, but also playing to traditional strengths like thoughtfully curating playlists and championing new artists.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Internet radio was supposed to squash small FM music stations like KEXP. Someone forget to tell that to KEXP, the little station that has helped start the careers of big music acts like the Lumineers and Macklemore and Ryan Lewis.

articles.headline: Hollywood Is Producing Higher Highs, Lower Lows
articles.snippet: This year may set new marks for both hits and misses in the movie industry.
articles.abstract: This year may set new marks for both hits and misses in the movie industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, American moviegoers have either been going big or staying home.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Tricked and Indebted on Land, Abused or Abandoned at Sea
articles.snippet: Illegal “manning agencies” trick villagers in the Philippines with false promises of high wages and send them to ships notorious for poor safety and labor records.
articles.abstract: Illegal “manning agencies” trick villagers in the Philippines with false promises of high wages and send them to ships notorious for poor safety and labor records.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINABUAN SUR, the Philippines — When Eril Andrade left this small village, he was healthy and hoping to earn enough on a fishing boat on the high seas to replace his mother’s leaky roof.

articles.headline: Myanmar Election Has Aung San Suu Kyi’s Party Confident of Landslide
articles.snippet: The military-backed ruling party acknowledged its poor showing in the landmark elections, whose results were still being tabulated on Monday.
articles.abstract: The military-backed ruling party acknowledged its poor showing in the landmark elections, whose results were still being tabulated on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — After struggling against the heavy hand of the Burmese military for two and a half decades, the opposition party of the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi said Monday that it was confident of a sweeping victory in the country’s landmark nationwide elections.
